snippet: In 1935, the year before Jesse Owens won four gold medals at the Berlin Olympics, a sprinter from New Jersey named Eulace Peacock beat Owens in race after race.
abstract: William C Rhoden Sports of The Times column on famed American sprinter Jesse Owens and his compelling rival Eulace Peacock; notes that Peacock repeatedly beat Owens in 1935, the year before Owens won four gold medals at the Berlin Olympics, yet Peacock became an asterisk in the annals of history because of an ill-timed injury; says that Peacock is a prime example of the 'what if' moments of sports, and life. Photos (M)
lead_paragraph: A new PBS documentary details the life of Jesse Owens before and after his historic performance at the 1936 Berlin Olympics. Laurens Grant's film hits many familiar themes and surprises with others, but one of its gems is Owens's compelling rivalry with Eulace Peacock, one of the few contemporary sprinters who, during a stretch in 1935, had Owens's number. The popular approach to Owens is to race past the guts of his competitive career to show how Owens stuck it to Hitler and Nazi Germany. Often overlooked is that Owens was a flesh and blood human being who had challenges.

headline.main: In Rival for Owens, Questions of What Might Have Been
